column3: Use the momentum principle to compute the future motion of a system given its current state.
Use the momentum principle to infer forces acting on a system given its current motion.
Draw and label free body diagrams.
Compute forces directly due to fundamental interactions.
Compute forces arising from contact interactions.
Relate concepts between microscopic and macroscopic perspectives.
Describe curving motion in terms of the rates of change of velocity, position, and momentum.
Compute the change of a system's energy based on the system's initial and final state.
Compute the Work done on a system by a force or the energy transferred between a system and the surroundings.
Use the Energy Principle to make inferences about the initial state, final state, work done, or energy transferred between a system and the surroundings.
Apply the Energy Principle in situations where multiple forms of energy (e.g., rotational, vibrational, etc.) are important.
Use the angular momentum principle to compute the future motion of a system given its current state.
Compute the number of microstates available to a system given the energy distribution among sub-systems.
Apply the Energy Principle in situations where the energy is quantized.
Write a computer program to compute the future motion of a system given the forces of interaction
Write a computer program to compute the number of micro states available to a system given the distribution of energy among sub-systems.
Estimate the parameters of a model based on data collected in an experiment.
Compare the measured motion of a system to the prediction of the momentum principle.
Compare the measured static and dynamic spring stiffnesses of a spring.
Estimate the drag coefficient of a falling object.
Compare the measured behavior of a system to the prediction of the energy principle.
